author: potuz
content: The problem is that in the current model all miners have nothing invested in ETH close to the merge, so there's no need for them to protect the network at all, and expecting them to do this out of an altruistic principle is naive. So we need to find a way of not just simply "pay for security" but to actually pay in a way that the payment does guarantee security somehow

author: potuz
content: Seems like quite a complicated problem in every front

author: potuz

author: schone_wizard

author: potuz
content: That I cannot answer, I can say some that seemed reasonable to me 1) pay miners to continue mining after the merge, but do so in the beaconchain so that they are invested in ETH2. 2) Simply mint eth to the EF and buy whatever hashrate is there in nicehash if the available hashrate becomes dangerous.

author: potuz
content: there are more, but all have some problem, and none is actually satisfactory and trustless. This seems like a very hard problem at least to me. Although I highly suspect it's a bit inflated, I just simply doubt that there are enough bad actors that at the same time have the social skills to coordinate such a thing, so perhaps simply paying the largest 3-4 public pools is enough

author: definitelynotcharles7176
content:
In the "MEV call" with Micah, he laid out various scenarios, such as a giant BR for the final block and sustained periods of mining empty blocks post merge. These all seemed reasonable.

As a side comment, I think having EF and the Devs communicate differently and use a strategy of governance and good faith is worth alot.

I don't think "this is a dark forest, let's see what the game theory says" should be the number 1 go to, and that is 100% the impression miners have of EF outlook. 

Saying "Hey, miners are stakeholders and we don't pull the rug out from people we work with" has a lot of value. 

In any normal org this is quite believable, esp. since the costs are not large and borne uniformly by everyone when you say you will pay 3-12 months post merge.

This is just how normal institutions work and probably just makes everything more workable and easier.
